history.content: You can list them on your resume, and if you want the commits to show up in your activity log, there's a Github option for that. Publishing your code would not be a good idea; worst case, if an employer really wants to see the code, you can always transmit it privately.

children.subject: To add on, I think it's great to put those projects on (especially ones where you did extra) when you don't have anything else, but only put 1 or 2 and make sure to remove them as soon as you have better things to write about.
You can put them in private repos on GitHub or Bitbucket and give access to recruiting staff.

I would be wary of using school projects as some recruiters, especially Berkeley Alums, will easily see they are simply school projects. Too many students act as if a school project was something they made from scratch, and lying is never a very good idea on your resume. Additionally, if even two other people have the same project on their resumes, yours is quickly discredited.

history.content: A Career Center adviser I met with recommend me including more projects on my resume, mentioning how some of the projects in the intro CS courses (eg. CS61A's ants and some bees, CS61B's Editor and Maps projects). I'm not sure how I should be doing this though as to put them on a public Github account included on my resume would allow students taking the classes now to find my code. Any suggestions?
history.subject: Including Class Projects on Resumes
